title: Bulgaria boss apologises to England players for racist abuse despite saying he hadn't heard chants
text:

Bulgaria coach Krasimir Balakov has staged a dramatic U-turn and issued a public apology to England players who were subjected to racist abuse on Monday night.

Balakov could now even resign in the wake of the fall-out from the shameful night in Sofia which has shocked the whole of football.

Ex-World Cup star Balakov, 53, refused on the night to accept that he had heard any racist abuse when quizzed by Mirror Sport and also did not back down from his previous assertion that England has as much of a problem with racism as Bulgaria.

But Balakov issued a public statement on Wednesday to apologise after both Tyrone Mings and Raheem Sterling were targeted during England’s 6-0 win.

(Image: PA)

Balakov said: “My comments prior to the game versus England – that Bulgaria did not have trouble with racism – were based on the fact that the local championship has not seen such an issue on a large scale.

“There might have been isolated cases, but it is definitely not something that you see at the stadium.

“The majority of football fans do not participate in such chants and I believe this also to have been the case in the game against England.

“I would like to state one thing very clearly – since there have been reported cases of racial discrimination at the stadium in Sofia I, as Bulgaria national team head coach, would like to offer my sincere apologies to the English footballers and to anyone who felt offended.”

(Image: Getty Images)

Balakov was ridiculed on the night as TV coverage picked up very clearly monkey chants and also booing and jeering when Sterling touched the ball.

Manchester City star Sterling even brilliantly mocked Balakov on Twitter by posting a story of him claiming England had as big a problem with a reply saying: “Mmmmh ... Not sure about this one chief.”

Reports in Bulgaria suggest that Balakov - who played in the Bulgarian team which finished fourth in the 1994 World Cup - could now quit after FA president Borislav Mihaylov was forced to offer his resignation.

Mihaylov had entered into a war of words with Gareth Southgate and the FA after also denying Bulgaria had a problem with racism before the game even though their stadium had been partially closed for a previous offence.

(Image: Eddie Keogh for The FA/REX)

UEFA have now charged Bulgaria after the England game and have launched a full scale investigation which could see them get a full stadium ban.

However, there has been a backlash in Bulgaria against Mihaylov’s resignation as the public feel he has been made a scapegoat by the Government while the FA offices in Sofia were raided by police on Tuesday. Mihaylov was the man who appointed Balakov.

That highlights that some fans still believe the problems surrounding the England game have been overblown and they do not want Mihaylov to quit.

Meanwhile, five Bulgarian football fans suspected of racially abusing England players have been arrested. Bulgaria's Ministry of the Interior said: “Work is still ongoing to identify others.”
description: Ex-World Cup star Balakov refused on the night to accept that he had heard any racist abuse when quizzed by Mirror Sport
authors: Eddie Keogh For The Fa Rex
